body.p:
Copy
Know all Men, by these Presents, that Before me
George Lennon-Hunt--Her Britannic
Majesty's--Consul--in this City of Rio de Janeiro
personally appeared Abraham E. Christian--
Master of the British Brig - “Bolivar”--
Markus Nelson--Mate and Frank Nelson, Seaman
and these appearers voluntarily declared, that they sailed and departed in---
and with the said ---Brig---------
from-- New York---on the Thirteenth---
day of-July---last laden with a Cargo of
General Merchandize and bound to Yokohama---
that at the time of sailing as aforesaid, the said--Brig-----
was stanch, tight and strong, and well and properly manned, fitted, and equipped, for the
performance of the voyage.------------------------------------
That the weather was fine and
nothing of importance occured until the
20th of the same month the first part of
which day was very stormy with a high
cross sea in which the vessel laboured and
strained very much causing her to make a
peat deal more water than usual. That the
following day was more moderate but on the
22nd it again blew a hard gale accompanied
by violent rain squalls and a mountainous
Sea in which the vessel laboured and

strained very heavily and shipped large
quantities of water over all, sail was--
seduced as circumstances required and the
Pumps constantly attended to in order to
keep her free as she was leaking badly.
That later in the day it became necessary to
carry a heavy press of canvass to keep the
Vessel as much as possible clear of the Seas. On
the following day the wind abated a little and
the Sea consequently became somewhat smoother
but a heavy swell still kept up and the vessel
solled very much and continued to leak very
badly. That from the foregoing date up to the
13th of August the weather for the most part
was moderate and fine but the vessel continued
to make a great deal of water say on an
average about 500 strokes per hour rendering
it necessary to keep the Pumps constantly going,
on the above date however the weather
was very unsettled an upon one occasion

a heavy squall struck the ship with such
violence that before they could reduce
sail the Flying Zib and Main Topsail
were split to pieces. That during the
greater part of the following day the weather
was very boisterous and stormy accompanied
by a high head sea in which the Vessel
pitched and laboured heavily large -
bodies of water frequently coming inboard
flooding the deck fore and aft and the
vessel made so much water that it became
necessary to keep the Pumps constantly going.
That towards the latter past of the day
it moderated and the voyage was -
prosecuted without the occurrence of -
anything of importance, with the exception
that the Vessel made a great deal of water
keeping the Pumps constantly going, until
the 29th of August when they again

encountered a stormy gale with a high sea
running and the Vessel laboured heavily
and shipped large bodies of water
on deck sail was reduced as necessary
and the Pumps attended to. That it
continued to blow very strong accompanied
by violent squall at times and a high Sea
during the whole of the 30th and part of
the following day, and upon one occasion
they were struck by a heavy squall from
the Southwind which split the Foresail
and upper Fore Topsail. That the Vessel -
laboured and obtained excessives in the
heavy sea which prevailed and shipped
immense bodies of water overall she
also leaked very badly. That the weather
during the 1st + 2nd of September was moderate but on the
3rd finding that the Vessel continued to make
a great deal of water and the probability
of the leak increasing, it being as much

as could be done to Keep her free even in fine
weather and the crew also beeing almost worn
out it was considered advisable for the
safety and benefit of all concerned to put
into the nearest port and accordingly the
course was shaped for Rio de Janeiro and on
the 6th of the same month at about 1.45. P.M.
the "Bolivar" was safely anchored in this Harbour
and on the 9th
the aforesaid Master duly noted
his Protest in this Consulate
And because of the aforesaid evil events, the said appearers have declared to protest, and
have required from the prenominated Consul, an act to serve and avail them, and all
others concerned, when and where occaison may require. I do therefore in conformity
with such request, and in a serious, and solemn manner, protest against the winds and seas,
and all other causes and things, for all losses, costs, damages, expenses, and prejudices,
that have arisen, or been occasioned, or that may hereafter arise, or be caused, to these
appearers or others concerned, in consequence of the premises, in order and to the end,
tha all such losses, costs, damages, expenses, and pejudices, may be borne, suffered, and
sustained, and paid and made good by those to whom of right, it doth or may belong, to
bear, suffer, and sustain and pay, and mak good the same, in time, and place, suitable.

Thus done and protested, the said appearers have hereunto subscribed their names at
Rio de Janeiro, this seventh day of November
One Thousand Eight Hundred and sixy-seven.
(sigs) A. E. Christian
M. Nelson
Frank Nelson
In Testimonium Aeritaetis.
(ss) G. Lennon-Hunt.
H.B.M.Consul.
I the Undersigned Her Britannie
Majesty's Consul do herbey certify that the
-- foregoing is a true and correct copy
of the original Protest recorded in the Archives
at this Consulate.
Given under my hand and official
Seal at Rio de Janeiro this 27th. day
of November 1867
G. LennonHunt.
